parts:
Peter (Pete) Hegseth is an American government official, military veteran, and former television host.

Key points about him:

- Full name: Peter Brian Hegseth, born June 6, 1980, in Minneapolis, Minnesota. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
- Current role (as of 2025–2026): 29th United States Secretary of Defense under President Donald Trump (the administration has also promoted the older title “Secretary of War,” though the statutory name is still Secretary of Defense). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
- Background:
  - U.S. Army / Army National Guard officer (Iraq and Afghanistan veteran), rank of Major, recipient of multiple commendations including two Bronze Star Medals. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
  - Education: B.A. in politics from Princeton University; Master in Public Policy from Harvard. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
  - Former executive with veterans’ advocacy groups such as Vets for Freedom and Concerned Veterans for America. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
- Media career: Became a Fox News contributor in 2014 and later co‑hosted *Fox & Friends Weekend* from 2017 to 2024, which made him a prominent conservative media personality. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  
- Author: Has written several conservative-leaning books, including *In the Arena* (2016), *American Crusade* (2020), *Battle for the American Mind* (2022), and *The War on Warriors* (2024). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pete_Hegseth?utm_source=openai))  

If you’re asking about a particular aspect—his political views, military record, Fox News years, or his current role at the Pentagon—say which, and I can focus on that.
